Draft a GAML code snippet to generate a visually appealing histogram-type bar chart with the following specifications:


- Begin by setting up a `display` with the identifier `nice_bar_chart` configured to render in 2D.
- Inside this display, establish a chart titled "Nice Cumulative Bar Chart". This chart should be defined with a histogram type.
- Set the background color to dark blue (`#darkblue`) and the color for bars to light green (`#lightgreen`).
- Define the chart axes color to also be light green (`#lightgreen`).
- Customize the font settings for various elements of the chart:
 - Set the title font to 'Serif', with a size of 32.0 and style `italic`.
 - Configure the tick font to 'Monospaced', size 14, with a `bold` emphasis.
 - Assign the label font to 'Arial', size 18, and also `bold`.
 - For the legend, choose 'SanSerif', size 14, and style it `bold`.
- Control the vertical range of the chart (`y_range`) to be between -20 and 40.
- Determine the vertical axis tick unit (`y_tick_unit`) to be 10.
- Label the horizontal axis as 'Nice Xlabel' and the vertical axis as 'Nice Ylabel'.
- Include within the chart definition, the following three datasets with individual characteristics:
 - Dataset "BCC" should graph values using `10*cos(100*cycle)` and present a cumulative pattern (accumulate_values set to true). Employ a stacking style (`style:stack`) and color the bars yellow (`#yellow`).
 - Dataset "ABC" should plot values via `10*sin(100*cycle)` also in a stacked, cumulative fashion. Match the color of bars to blue (`#blue`).
 - Dataset "BCD" should represent values based on `(cycle mod 10)` and follow the same accumulation and stacking settings. Additionally, designate `marker_circle` as the marker shape used for this data.


Ensure the snippet generates an interactive and cumulative bar chart where the data dynamically accumulates over simulation cycles and the aesthetic choices deliver a "nice" thematic look.
prompts.answer:
display "nice_bar_chart"  type: 2d {
   chart "Nice Cumulative Bar Chart" type:histogram
       background: #darkblue
       color: #lightgreen
       axes: #lightgreen
       title_font: font('Serif', 32.0, #italic)
       tick_font: font('Monospaced', 14, #bold)
       label_font: font('Arial', 18, #bold)
       legend_font: font('SanSerif', 14, #bold)
       y_range:[-20,40]
       y_tick_unit:10
       x_label:'Nice Xlabel'
       y_label:'Nice Ylabel'
       {
       data "BCC" value:10*cos(100*cycle)
           accumulate_values: true                    
           style:stack
           color:#yellow;
       data "ABC" value:10*sin(100*cycle)
           accumulate_values: true                    
           style: stack
           color:#blue;
       data "BCD" value:(cycle mod 10)
           accumulate_values: true                    
           style: stack 
           marker_shape:marker_circle ;
   }
}

I have declared a field called "cells". Create an experiment called ShowCells of type gui. Add a 3d display called "Texture", which displays the field with a jpg texture file. Set the borders to black and enable triangulation.
generate an aspect called obj to display the agent using the my_obj.obj obj file oriented in the direction of the heading of the agent.

Generate a code snippet to create agents of species my_agents from the "data.csv" file reading the "name" column to init the name of attribute of the agents and the "age" column to init the age attribute of the agents.

I have defined a field in the global section. Create an experiment named Palettes with two 3d displays called "Brewer" and "Simple gradient". All the displays use triangulation. The first one uses the set3 from brewers colors. The second one must be a smooth color transition from darkgreen to white. For this latter, the borders of the mesh must be black.
I want both displays to be displayed at the same time. Moreover, the output must be sychronized with the simulation cycles.

I have a model called Overlay. In the global section, give the code of a map whith the following key/value pairs:
"water": #blue
"vegetation": #green
"building": #pink

Create an action named generate to create an realistic random terrain.
Put the code in the global section.

In the global section I have a boolean variable called dark_mode. In the experiment section of my model, add a parameter with the title "Toggle dark mode", tracking the value of the dark_mode variable.
Provide the whole architecture of the model.

Create a basic species called Animal represented as a 3d red sphere.
Instanciate it in a basic experiment.

I want to create a wizard with 2 fields. The first allows to upload a file from my computer. The other one must be a dropdown menu in which choices are "circle" and "square".
Name the wizard "Options" and add a subtitle "Choose the simulation options".
Create the wizard in the init statement of the global section.
